section.title: Introduction
section.para: The Powerline Toolkit has been developed with embedded applications in mind but it is not an embedded turn-key system. The Atheros Toolkit will cross-compile and run on several embedded controllers but Atheros does not claim to support cross-compilation for any particular environment or guarantee proper program execution on all hardware platforms. Customers should have (or obtain) embedded system expertise or allow time to develop the expertise before attempting any embedded project.

Many embedded systems use NVRAM for persistent storage. When power is applied, an image is read from NVRAM into SDRAM and executed. The image contains an operating system kernel and filesystem image. The kernel mounts the filesystem image and starts applications found there. This filesystem stores application programs, support libraries and configuration files and should have enough free space for temporary files that might be needed. A common system uses Linux as the operating system kernel, Busybox as the principle application and uClib as the support library. All executable components must be compiled for the target host processor instruction set.

section.title: Connections
section.para: The ADM5120 has several communication ports including one internal serial port, two external usb ports and two ethernet interfaces with five ethernet ports. The ethernet ports are configured as a gateway where that four ports service a Local Area Network (LAN) interface and the fifth port services a Wide Area Network (WAN) interface.

section.title: USB-to-Serial Port Connection
section.para: Since most of our computers do not have an external serial port we obtained a USB-to-serial cable and modified the serial connector for the interal ADM5120 serial connector. The following steps explain how to connect to the AMD5120 using a USB-to-serial cable and communicate with it using the minicom terminal emulation program. The serial port characteristics are 115200 bps, 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity, no hardware flow control, no software flow control.

listitem.para: Connect the serial end of the USB serial cable to the interal ADM5120 serial connector and power on the ADM5120 device. Let device will boot up as you perform the next steps.
Plug the USB serial adapter into the ubuntu host. Confirm that device /dev/ttyUSB0 have been created. This device is now the USB serial port.
Configure the minicom program by opening a console window and typing the command minicom -s. A text-based popup window should appear displaying the minicom configuration menu.
Use the cursor keys to select option Serial port setup then press Enter. Another text-based popup window should appear displaying serial port parameters.
listitem.screen: +-----------------------------------------------------------------------+ | A - Serial Device : /dev/ttyUSB0 | | B - Lockfile Location : /var/lock | | C - Callin Program : | | D - Callout Program : | | E - Bps/Par/Bits : 115200 8N1 | | F - Hardware Flow Control : No | | G - Software Flow Control : No | | | | Change which setting? | +-----------------------------------------------------------------------+

listitem.para: Press the letter A to select the Serial Device and type /dev/ttyUSB0 then press Enter. This assumes you are using a USB-to-serial cable; otherwise, name the appropriate tty device.
Press the letter E to select the Bps/Par/Bits and type 115200 8N1 then press Enter.
Press the letter F to toggle Hardware Flow Control until it indicates No.
Press the letter F to toggle Software Flow Control until it indicates No.
Press Enter when done to close the Serial port setup window and return to the configuration window.
Use the cursor keys to select option Filenames and paths and press Enter. Another text-based popup window should appear displaying various pathname options.
listitem.screen: +-----------------------------------------------------------------------+ | A - Download directory : /home/mydir/AMiLDA | | B - Upload directory : /home/mydir/AMiLDA | | C - Script directory : | | D - Script program : runscript | | E - Kermit program : | | F - Logging options | | | | Change which setting? | +-----------------------------------------------------------------------+

listitem.para: Press the letter A to select the Download directory then type a valid pathname then press Enter.
Press the letter B to select the Upload directory then type a valid pathname then press Enter.
Minicom truncates long pathnames without giving any immediate indication so keep your pathnames short.

The AMiLDA build stream places file vmlinuz in folder /usr/src/AMiLDA/linux-2.4.32-amilda/ by default but that pathname is too long and will be truncated. You may want to modify the build stream to place the file in another location or copy the file to another location or create a symlink to the file from another location.
Use the cursor keys to select option Save setup as dfl then press Enter. This will save your setting as file /etc/minicom/minirc.dfl.

Use the cursor keys to select option Exit and press Enter to close the configuration window and start the minicom program. Assuming the ADM5120 is properly connected and powered up, you should see the Linux login prompt in the console window.

section.title: Bootloader Menu
section.para: Power cycle the ADM5120 board to see the boot prompt. You will have about two or three seconds to press the space three times before the the Linux system starts to bootload. If you are fast enough then you should see the following menu and be able to download a new vmlinuz image into either SDRAM or NVRAM via a menu.

example.title: ADM5120 Boot Menu
example.screen:
ADM5120 Boot:
Linux Loader Menu ==================== (a) Download vmlinuz to flash ... (b) Download vmlinuz to sdram (for debug) ... (c) Exit
Please enter your key :

section.para: After typing either a or b, you will have about 8 seconds to commence an XMODEM protocol download of you image file. The actual filename is not important but the file format is important. If you select option b then the image file can be a standard Linux vmlinuz file. If you select option a then the image file must a standard Linux image file with header and checksum. If you select option c, either the flashed or the downloaded vmlinuz image will execute and proceed to a login prompt.

Although minicom can be used to download firmware images, Atheros recommends using scripts download.sh and flash.sh, instead. They are easier to use and are more reliable. See Downloading Images for more information about these scripts.

Atheros has been experimenting with the AMiLDA distribution for the AMD5120. The AMiLDA distribution includes a Linux kernel, the Busybox application and the uClib library. Atheros has integrated the Powerline Toolkit into a copy of this distribution for our own use.

This section documents the steps needed to compile AMiLDA. The information is taken from public information available on the internet and our own experiences with AMiLDA. Atheros does not endorse, recommend or support this hardwaer or software in any way. We merely provide some information as a courtesy to customers who may be interested.

listitem.para: Obtain the Edimax toolchain, tool-chain.tar.gz, and save it in any location that your prefer.

Extract the Edimax toolchain to the root filesystem folder. The toolchain must be located there or compile errors will occur. The resulting folder, /export/tools, contains a pre-compiled set of build tools for the ADM5120 that will execute in place of the normal tools installed on your system whenever the AMiLDA build stream is executed.
Obtain the AMiLDA source tree and save it in any location that your prefer.

Extract the AMiLDA source tree to the folder /usr/src. The source tree must be located there or compile errors will occur. The resulting folder, /usr/src/AMiLDA, contains a Linux kernel and custom applications.
Before attempting a compile the kernel, install the bison and flex packages. This should install contemporary yacc-style and lex-style components needed by the kernel build stream.
From folder /usr/src/AMiLDA execute command make clean to purge old kernel and application object files and temporary files created by previous builds.
From folder /usr/src/AMiLDA/linux-2.4.32 execute command make oldconfig to build a new .config file.

If you encouter an error indicating that folder include/asm cannot be deleted because it is a directory then manually delete the directory with the command rm -fr include/asm. The folder will be replaced with a symbolic link during the build process. The folder contents is sometime included when the tree it archived because it is a symbolic link.
In folder /usr/src/AMiLDA/linux-2.4.32 execute command make dep to build new kernel files.
In folder /usr/src/AMiLDA execute command make to build new system. This operation takes some time to complete.

section.title: Firmware Images
section.para: The Atheros build stream creates two firmware image files. File AMiLDA/linux/vmlinuz is a standard Linux image file. It can be dowloaded directly into ADM5120 SDRAM and temporarily executed there. File AMiLDA/image/vmlinuz is an encapsulated version of the standardLinux image having an header and checksum. It can be dowloaded and flashed into ADM5120 NVRAM for permanent execution.

Program AMiLDA/image/cvimg can be used to convert the standard Linux image file, AMiLDA/linux/vmlinuz, to an encapsulated image file. AN encapsulated image file is the only one needed to replicate your system on multiple ADM5120 devices. You may also want to distribute script flash.sh, described in the next section, with the encapsulated image.

section.title: Downloading Images
section.para: Atheros does not recommend using minicom to download and flash firmware because it can be awkward to configure and change. Instead, we recomend using one of the two expect scripts included with our build stream. Establish a serial connection to the ADM5120, start one of the scripts then power-cycle the ADM5120. The script will monitor the serial line for Boot Menu prompts and respond by downloading and flashing or executing the appropriate image.

Both scripts are located in the AMiLDA folder. Both scripts have constants that name the serial device and download file. One script downloads and executed an image in SDRAM. The other downloads and flashes NVRAM then loads the image into SDRAM and executes it.

Close all serial connections to the ADM5120 before running either script or download will fail. Start one of the scripts and power-cycle the ADM5120. Downloading should begin almost at once. Examples are shown below. Open a serial connection only after dowloading terminates.

Please enter your key : Sending /usr/src/AMiLDA/linux/vmlinuz, 11165 blocks: Give your local XMODEM receive command now. Xmodem sectors/kbytes sent: 3965/495k
example.para: Script flash.sh downloads the encapsulated image file AMiLDA/image/vmlinuz then flashes NVRAM using option a on the ADM5120 boot menu.

section.para: To use these scripts, you must first install the Linux expect application. On GNU Linux based distributions, the command apt-get install expect will download and install it. Other distributions will require different commands.

Busybox is a monolithic application program that implements most standard GNU utilities included in many Linux distributions. The AMiLDA distribution used by Atheros includes Busybox-1.10.0 and Linux-2.4.32. These two components provide a nearly complete operating environment.
Atheros has made no changes to Linux and only a few changes Busybox as provided.

section.title: Ramdisk
section.para: Folder AMiLDA/ramdisk contains the Makfile that creates a compressed filesystem image that is loaded into SDRAM and mounted when Linux boots. You should study this Makefile carefully because most system changes will require changes here.

Essentially, this Makefile creates a temporary folder, mounts it as an ext2 filesystem, populates it with required folders and files, unmounts it and compresses it. The compressed image is ultimately included in the image file AMiLDA/linux/vmlinuz.

This section covers the folders and files needed for proper operation of the Powerline Toolkit. It does not cover any other folders and files that may be needed by components of the AMiLDA environment.

section.title: Atheros Toolkit
section.para: The Atheros Toolkit requires folder /usr/local/bin to be present on the ramdisk. This folder must be created and desired programs should be copied there. Additionally, this folder should be added to the user environment, in some way, because it is not part of the standard Busybox environment.

section.title: Web Interface
section.para: The Atheros Toolkit web interfaces requires the following folders and files to be present on the ramdisk.

listitem.para: Contains the main application program, intellon.cgi, that receives and services CGI requests sent from the client browser. This folder must be created on the ramdisk and desired application programs copied to it. In addition, this folder should be added to the user environment, in some way, on login since is is not part of the standard Busybox environment.
Contains the main application stylesheet, amilda.css. This folder must be creted on the ramdisk and the ctylesheet must be copied to it.
Contains application images. This folder must be created on the ramdisk and the required images copied to it.

Contains the application session variable, intellon.dat. This folder must be created on the ramdisk, if it does not already exist, or the web interace will not preserve information from one session to the next. A default session variable may be copied here, but it is not required, because it is dynamically created.

section.title: Atheros Toolkit
section.para: The Powerline Toolkit may be installed as part of the AMiLDA environment when space permits. The toolkit needs the Linux kernel and uClib library to function; however, the toolkit web interface also needs an HTTP server with CGI enabled. The web interfaces is an independent application that does not rely on any other toolkit programs for proper operation.

section.title: Integration
section.para: This section explains how to integrate and cross-compile the Powerline Toolkit for the ADM5120. It assumes that you have installed the Edimax toolchain and AMiLDA distribution as described in the Compiling section.

listitem.para: Obtain the latest version of the Powerline Toolkit archive and save it anwhere that your prefer. The archive filename will reflect the toolkit version and so plc-utils-x.x.x, used here, refers to whatever version you have.

Extract the toolkit into folder /usr/src/AMiLDA/apps. The resulting folder should have the same name as the archive file and not overwrite previous versions. You may either keep or discard earlier versions, depending on your requirements.

From folder /usr/src/AMiLDA/apps, create a symbolic link to the new toolkit folder. This link allows scripts to access the correct version of the toolkit using a constant pathname so make sure the link is correct. A common problem is forgetting to set this link correctly.

Edit file /usr/src/AMiLDA/app/linux/make.def. Uncomment the two lines that define symbols CROSS and CROSS_LINUX. The standard definitions assume that you installed the Edimax toolchain as described in the Compiling section. If not then change the definitions to reflect the actual location.

From folder /usr/src/AMiLDA/apps/linux, cross-compile the toolkit using the cross-compile toolchain that you defined in the previous step. Save build errors and warnings to file compile.log then inspect the file afterwards. Warnings are permitted but errors are not. You should have virtually no warnings.
listitem.screen: # make clean # make 2> compile.log # cat compile.log

section.para: The toolkit is now cross-compiled for the ADM5120. There is no need to re-compile unless you make changes. Subsequent AMiLDA compilation will automatically compile the toolkit via dependencies defined in file /usr/src/AMiLDA/apps/Makefile.

section.title: HTTP Interface
section.para: The Atheros HTTP interface is a prototype that demonstrates one way to remotely inspect and manage a network of Atheros devices in a host independent manner. The key features are simplicity and small size. The only environmental requirements are an HTTP web server that supports CSS2 and CGI and enough space to store the application and image files.

The interface application consists of one CGI program image and one (or two) image files. Major components are located in the toolkit cgi folder. Minor components are located in neighboring toolkit folders. The application is not automatically compiled or installed when the toolkit is compiled or installed. It must be compiled and installed independently using the Makefile found in the cgi folder. The Makefile has variables that define installation target folders.

The interface can be compiled on any Linux host then tested using a web server, such as Apache, with CSS2 and CGI support enabled. The application can then be cross-compiled for other targets and downloaded when ready.
